EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

p.label: 18. Q.

VÅ¿e. Be carefull (my child) to watch with all care and diligence, in thy Å¿oule, about theÅ¿e covetings. Have Å¿uch a quiet

VÅ¿e. Oh (my child) feare, and tremble under this burthen. Thou art apt (as all others) to build up thy way to heaven with untempered morter, Å¿aying to thy own Å¿oule, that all is well, when all is amiÅ¿Å¿e. This makes thee, with an hard,

Robert Abbot doth dedicate theÅ¿e three enÅ¿uing Sermons, as a teÅ¿timony of my deareÅ¿t reÅ¿pects to that Noble Family, and doth humbly pray for their Å¿ouls and bodies happineÅ¿Å¿es to Eternall Glory.
div.p:
MY Noble Friends, God hath joyned you together by bloud, and marriage, and I durÅ¿t not Å¿eparate one from the other. It is all your goods I ayme at, and therefore I reÅ¿olved not to make one beholding to another for a gift, but all to bee thankefull to that Noble Mother, who Å¿et me on work. On my part, I can do
nothing that may deÅ¿erve a publike eye: but if others think otherwiÅ¿e, I cannot help it. If they tell me that I have a talent; I have known that a long time. If they tell me it may profit by way of preaching, I muÅ¿t put that to the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e which Gods bleÅ¿sing will give it. If they tell me it may profit by writing, here onely I Å¿tick. I am altogether ignorant what I can do in this kinde. I have nothing to direct me but others opinions and deÅ¿ires: and if they be no Å¿ure Cards and CompaÅ¿Å¿es to Å¿ail by into this cenÅ¿uring world, I may Å¿uffer Å¿hipwrack. HowÅ¿oever it fall out, I muÅ¿t now take my Lot, and if with Jonas I be caÅ¿t into the Sea, it is becauÅ¿e I have obeyed, and not becauÅ¿e I have rebelled. It is poÅ¿sible for a man to know when he is called to do any work, though it be a work of hazard. He is called, Å¿urely, when he hath a voice from heaven to deÅ¿igne him as Paul had; and when he hath a particular inÅ¿tinct of Å¿pirit, as many worthies in the firÅ¿t ages; and when he hath the propheÅ¿ies go of him, as Timothy had; and when he hath the approbation, and impoÅ¿ition of hands of the ElderÅ¿hip, as ordinary Å¿ervants of ChriÅ¿t for the benefit of the Church, PaÅ¿tours, and Teachers have; or laÅ¿tly, when
he hath the engagement of the hearts of Gods people attending upon his diÅ¿penÅ¿ing of the myÅ¿teries of grace, and preÅ¿sing the publike uÅ¿e of what he doth more privately. As I have had long ago, and ever Å¿ince, Å¿ome comfortable approbation at, and Å¿ince the impoÅ¿ition of hands, Å¿o have I had Å¿ome cloÅ¿ing of the hearts of the godly, for the bringing into the publike, of what I have done in this Å¿ervice, in the private. This I have accounted an invitation to do Å¿omething by the pen, as well as in the Pulpit. As I would not be Å¿o running out, as to make all my diviner thoughts viÅ¿ible to the Sunne (becauÅ¿e there are many that can do it better): Å¿o would I not be Å¿o bound up, as to be unwilling to profit Å¿ome in this way, though others may think it not worth the looking on. That which is as gold to Å¿ome, may be as braÅ¿Å¿e to others: and that which is as Å¿ilver to Å¿ome, is as lead to others: and yet variety of Å¿pirits may be helped according to various touches, and impreÅ¿sions, of fancies, judgements, conceptions, and opinions from the Å¿pirit of ChriÅ¿t.

I therefore being emboldened to do Å¿omething in this kinde, was not long to Å¿tudy to whoÅ¿e hands to preÅ¿ent it firÅ¿t, and thence to have it derived to all EngliÅ¿h hands, and
hearts, that we are willing to receive it. To you therefore (my noble friends) is it come, onely craving your acceptance, according to the worth of the matter, not of the perÅ¿on that exhibits it unto you. I am a poor old man, clogged with many infirmities, who have been toÅ¿Å¿ed, and bandied up, and down in the world; who yet, want nothing but a fuller meaÅ¿ure of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t to dwell in my Å¿oul by faith. I have learned you the fountains of Å¿ecret Å¿innes, and the means how to diÅ¿cover them in your Å¿elves, that it may bow you before the God of heaven, to make you fit to hold JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. It muÅ¿t be an hollow veÅ¿Å¿el which muÅ¿t hold water, and an hollowed heart; that muÅ¿t lye under the fountain of David for Å¿in and for uncleanneÅ¿Å¿e, to carry away the water of life to the Å¿oul. I have taught you the worth of the Glorious GoÅ¿pel, that you may be willing to hunt after ChriÅ¿t, and, when you have found him, to part with all that is yours for his embracements. And, becauÅ¿e your precious Å¿ouls are in much danger in theÅ¿e diÅ¿tracted dayes, both by proÅ¿perity, and adverÅ¿ity, I have learned you, from the beÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿urance office in the world, to Å¿ecure your Å¿ouls; that while you enjoy them you may have faith, while you have faith, you
may have ChriÅ¿t, and while you have ChriÅ¿t, you may have the love of God for your eternall good.

I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, that if ever ChriÅ¿tian Å¿ouls were in danger, they are in danger now. We are faln into the laÅ¿t, and perillous dayes: wherein while the Drum, and Canon are the beÅ¿t muÅ¿ick, and CommiÅ¿sion is given to the Å¿word to cut off not a few, and to guild the Land with crying bloud; the Enemy Å¿owes tares to an aboundance at home, to the hinderance of Reformation, and to the disjoynting of many a good Å¿oul. Some of the ancient exploded hereÅ¿ies are revived; and Å¿uch wide ruptures are made, that a devout Å¿oul can Å¿carce tell at which dore to go in to ChriÅ¿t: my heart bleeds to Å¿ee with what daring, and violence private opinions are maintained. I beleeve that I may have Å¿ome private opinion, of my own; but I will rather bury it within my breaÅ¿t, then Å¿uffer it to make a publike diÅ¿turbance. If others would do Å¿o too, we might (it may be) have been wafted to our wiÅ¿hed for haven before this day. But (alas) all cry up the ways of ChriÅ¿t, the ordinances of ChriÅ¿t, the Kingdome of Christ; but when it comes to be examined it is found to be nothing but Å¿elf opinions, and
Å¿elf practiÅ¿es. Some look upon the Law as a School-maÅ¿ter unto ChriÅ¿t, and, when they have learned him, they would walk in ChriÅ¿t, not onely by beleeving, but by doing, Å¿uch holy & charitable duties as the Law propounds and commands. Some would have no uÅ¿e of the Law among ChriÅ¿tians, but pin all upon faith, as if faith did not work by love. Some look upon BaptiÅ¿m as unuÅ¿efull in our Infantery, though the beginning of it cannot be concludently grounded but from the ApoÅ¿tles, and the practiÅ¿e of it was never oppoÅ¿ed till this laÅ¿t age. Some are for the grafting of it into the place of CircumciÅ¿ion; becauÅ¿e it can be no other then that was, A Å¿igne and Å¿eal of the righteouÅ¿nes of faith: and God, who caleth things that are not as if they were, calleth, by vertue of his Covenant, Infants of ChriÅ¿tians Believers, much more theÌ infants of Jews. Some again are for Congregationall Churches onely, as if ChriÅ¿t had given any Å¿uch precept, or as if there were any Å¿uch practiÅ¿e according to undoubted rule. Others will have ClaÅ¿sicall Churches under Å¿weet and amiable Å¿ubordination to help the Communion of Saints, as in the dayes of Timothy, and Titus. Some would have excommunication in the power of the whole Body; Å¿ome in the
power of the Presbytery; Å¿ome in the power of a mixt Presbytery, Å¿ome of an ElderÅ¿hip of MiniÅ¿tery, which Å¿eemes to be the righteÅ¿t way; and Å¿ome would have none at all, though, happly, if excommunication be not a delivering over to Satan; yet it may, juÅ¿tly, be a wary caÅ¿ting out, and removing Å¿tones of offence till they are humbled, and reformed. Some would have all puniÅ¿hments in the power of the MagiÅ¿trate; Å¿ome would have none but for Å¿uch faults as claÅ¿h againÅ¿t Publique Peace of the Common-wealth: though it cannot be denied, but that the Å¿word of a good MagiÅ¿trate, for vertue, and againÅ¿t vice is a back of Steele to a good MiniÅ¿tery. Some are for admittance of members of the Church by I know not what Covenant (becauÅ¿e it is variouÅ¿ly practiÅ¿ed). Others know no covenant but that of grace, made in BaptiÅ¿me, and renewed in the Supper of the Lord, except voluntary Covenants, and according to the Rules of ChriÅ¿tian libertie. Now (my much honoured friends) when theÅ¿e digladiations are Å¿harpned amongÅ¿t good men, great men, will it not be a beame in the eye of many a good Å¿oul, even to hinder them from walking with Å¿uch a Å¿teady foot, in the wayes of ChriÅ¿t, as were to be
wiÅ¿hed? I know no better way to help all, then to follow Melancthons counÅ¿ell to his Mother, when Å¿he was troubled with the controverÅ¿ies of her time, that Å¿he Å¿tick to her old principles of Å¿aving doctrine, and practiÅ¿e, and for the reÅ¿t to wait the iÅ¿Å¿ue of Gods providence. This is my humble, and hearty counÅ¿ell to you all. Look upon the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of every good man, and Å¿o far as you Å¿ee ChriÅ¿t in them, Å¿o far honour, and Å¿uccour them: but for other opinions engage you not. It will be more unÅ¿eemly at laÅ¿t to caÅ¿t out an errour, upon further triall, then not to admit it at firÅ¿t. God hath his mighty work in theÅ¿e Å¿tirrings, for the cleering of Å¿ome truths, yet, more confuÅ¿edly known. When this is brought unto an iÅ¿Å¿ue, it will more Å¿weetly content you, then a preÅ¿ent engagement in the premiÅ¿es of many Å¿tirring Å¿pirits who do too much trouble themÅ¿elves and others. This is all I ayme at, and therefore preÅ¿ent you with old quiet grounds of faith, and practiÅ¿e, as well becommeth me who am the Å¿ervant of JeÅ¿us Christ, and under him

div.p:
WE are come to an humbling day: and this is an humbling Text. It points at an infinite company of Å¿innes; but it laments & prays againÅ¿t Å¿ecret Å¿ins. Every Pulpit, all the Town, words it againÅ¿t open Å¿innes; and if we amend not, it is not for want of light, but for want of love to piety: but if we can make Å¿ome diÅ¿covery of Secret Å¿innes, it makes us Å¿uÅ¿pect the more thoÅ¿e that are known, and, it may be, caÅ¿ts us upon a bed of Å¿orrow for all, becauÅ¿e our Å¿ecret

David Å¿ues here to God for two bleÅ¿Å¿ings juÅ¿tification, and Å¿anctification. The motives to Å¿et him on, are the glory God hath by the Creatures, and by the word. By the creatures he is wonderfully glorified: V. 1, 2, 3, 4, &c. The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament Å¿hewes his handy-work. They glorifie God by working according to the Law which God hath put upon them: and by bearing forth impreÅ¿Å¿es of Gods MajeÅ¿ty, wiÅ¿edome, and goodneÅ¿Å¿e. By the word God is more glorified yet. VerÅ¿. 7, 8, 9, 10, &c. It is his law, his teÅ¿timonies, his Å¿tatutes, his commandements, and his fear. It is perfect, it is Å¿ure, it is right, it is pure, it is clean, it is truth, and righteous altogether. It converts, makes wiÅ¿e, rejoyceth, enlighteneth, and is everlaÅ¿ting. David was Å¿o in love with the glory that God had both theÅ¿e wayes, that, no doubt he was heartily wiÅ¿hing that all men would honour him too. But for himÅ¿elf, he Å¿ets himÅ¿elf earneÅ¿tly upon it: and becauÅ¿e he cannot do it without

Keep back preÅ¿umptuous Å¿innes, let them not have dominion over me: and laÅ¿tly for the fruit of both, let my words, Ver. 14. and meditations be acceptable in thy Å¿ight. He knew that praiÅ¿e is not comely for the mouth of a Å¿infull fool. He would not therefore care how farre he were from it, even from the whole body of it, that he might glorifie God as he Å¿hould.

The diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. The diÅ¿eaÅ¿e are Errours: Who can underÅ¿tand his errours? It is propounded interrogatorily by way of queÅ¿tion; who? and there are five kindes of interrogations in the Scriptures.
1. Dubitans.
PÅ¿. 77.7, 8, 9 A doubting queÅ¿tion: Will the Lord caÅ¿t off for ever? Will he be favourable no more? Is his mercy clean gone for ever? Doth his promiÅ¿e fail for evermore? Here, in caÅ¿e of deÅ¿ertion, the Prophet is full of doubts. 2. Docens.

Mar. 10.16. A Learning queÅ¿tion: What Å¿hall I do that I may poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e eternall life by inheritance? This is deÅ¿irous to learn the way to heaven. 4. Affirmans.
2 King. 12.19. 2 King. 14.18. An affirming queÅ¿tion: Å¿uch often in the book of the Kings: Are they not written in the Books of the Kings of Judah, and IÅ¿rael? They are: they Å¿tand in the publike records, and in their Chronicles. 5. Negans.
LaÅ¿tly, there is a denying queÅ¿tion: and Å¿uch is this here, Who can underÅ¿tand his errours? None can to the depth, and bottom. In this queÅ¿tion there are two conÅ¿iderables;
1 A ConceÅ¿Å¿ion.
2 A ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion.

He makes a grant, that our life is full of errours: A ConceÅ¿Å¿ion. and the Scriptures Å¿ay the Å¿ame, EÅ¿a. 53.6. PÅ¿. 119. ult. Math. 10.6. while they affirm, that all wee are like loÅ¿t Å¿heep: and I have gone aÅ¿tray like loÅ¿t Å¿heep: and the houÅ¿e of IÅ¿rael hath loÅ¿t Å¿heep. I need not reckon up the particulars, as the errours of our Å¿enÅ¿es, underÅ¿tandings, conÅ¿ciences, judgements, wils, affections, deÅ¿ires, actions, and occurrences. The whole man in nature is
like a tree nipt at root which brings forth worm-eaten fruits. The whole man in life, is like an inÅ¿trument out of tune, which jars at every Å¿troke. If we cannot underÅ¿tand them, certainly, they are very many.

VÅ¿e. 1 Therefore, we may wonder at Gods mercies towards us, and acknowledge, a wonderfull difficultie to Å¿tand under our burthens impoÅ¿ed by God. FirÅ¿t, we may wonder that God is mindfull of us, as David, PÅ¿al. 8. what is man that thou art mindfull of him, and the Sonne of man that thou doeÅ¿t Å¿o regard him? He is a thing of nothing: Nay, worÅ¿e then nothing. Nothing hath never offended God; but we have done nothing but offended him in our whole courÅ¿e. If we had but two, or three errours, it were the leÅ¿Å¿e wonder: but the wonder is, becauÅ¿e we have Å¿o many. We were as a piece of TapeÅ¿try curiouÅ¿ly wrought; PÅ¿al. 139.15. and now we are torne in pieces by Å¿inne, and Satan, and have errours to a wonder, and yet are laden with benefits, and crowned with loving kindneÅ¿Å¿e, and favours, on the right hand; and on the left. VÅ¿e 2 Secondly, feelingly acknowledge how hard it is to Å¿tand under our own burthens before God. Our many errours make great weakneÅ¿Å¿e in all our parts,
Facilitas cadendi, difficultas Å¿tandi, Imbecillitas Å¿urgendi, debilitas perÅ¿everandi. PÅ¿al. 38.4. Rom. 7.24. and powers. We are eaÅ¿ily drawn to fall, we are hardly able to Å¿tand, we are weake to ariÅ¿e when we are down, and unable to perÅ¿evere when we are up without a covenant of mercy. If David could not beare his burthen; nor Paul his burthen, what Å¿hall we doe, except we flye to the Å¿tronger man then he in the houÅ¿e, ChriÅ¿t in his way? Therefore as Benhadabs Å¿ervants came to Ahabs Å¿ervants with Å¿ackcloth, and ropes; Å¿o doe you come in humilitie to ChriÅ¿t, and Å¿ay, Oh Å¿eek thy Å¿ervant that puts his truÅ¿t in thee. If you doubt whether he will help you, being clothed with errours as with a garment: thinke that the Lord is thy Shepherd: PÅ¿al. 23.1. Joh. 10. and that ChriÅ¿t is the good Shepherd of his Å¿heep. Therefore as they defend their Å¿heep, as David did from the Lion, and the Beare: as they paÅ¿ture their Å¿heep, as MoÅ¿es did in baniÅ¿hment: as they water their Å¿heep, as the Patriarchs Å¿ervants,

Come next to the ConfeÅ¿sion. David hath granted that man hath many errours; and now he confeÅ¿Å¿eth, ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion. That We cannot know our errours. that we cannot know our errours. Put it to the queÅ¿tion, who can know his errours? The AnÅ¿wer is negative, man cannot know them: you will Å¿ay then, it is in vain to Å¿earch. True, if it were impoÅ¿sible for us to know them, or to know more then we do: but it is but difficult in it Å¿elf, and for us. But you will Å¿ay, on the other Å¿ide, why Å¿hould it be Å¿o difficult, 1 Cor. 2.11 when the Å¿pirit of a man doth know the things of a man. You will enquire after two things, how comes it that we know not our errours? and how we may be aÅ¿Å¿ured that we know
them not? It comes to paÅ¿Å¿e four wayes.

FirÅ¿t, How comes it that we know not our errours. from the infinite number of them. Infinite I Å¿ay, not with reference to God (for the imperfections of the creature cannot, numerally exceed the perfections of the creatures) but with reÅ¿pect to us. They are more then the haires of our heads, more then the Å¿ands of the Sea Å¿hore which cannot be told by us. Secondly, it comes to paÅ¿Å¿e from the root of hypocriÅ¿ie that is in us. This makes us not onely deceive others, Gal. 6.3. but our Å¿elves in our imaginations: and Å¿o, we think them few, when they are like the Army of the Aramites that covers the earth.

Thirdly, Plenitudinem, rectitudinem, & claritatem intellectus. it comes to paÅ¿Å¿e from the pravity and miÅ¿carriage of our underÅ¿tandings. We have loÅ¿t the fulneÅ¿Å¿e, the cleerneÅ¿Å¿e, and the rectitude of our underÅ¿tanding of good; and therefore we cannot underÅ¿tand our errours by the oppoÅ¿it good. LaÅ¿tly, it comes to paÅ¿Å¿e by the Å¿leepineÅ¿Å¿e of our conÅ¿ciences. If the Sentinel Å¿leep, who Å¿o will may come into the GariÅ¿on uneÅ¿pied. If the Shepheard Å¿leep, the whole flock may be overgrown with flye-blowes: Å¿o may thy Å¿oul with errours if conÅ¿cience be drowÅ¿ie, and have the Å¿pirit of Å¿lumber. It may be demonÅ¿trated, and we may be aÅ¿Å¿ured that we know not our errours three ways. FirÅ¿t, by our Å¿ecurity. How we may be aÅ¿Å¿ured that we know not our errours. Jud. 18.10. If a man live careleÅ¿ly as the children of LaiÅ¿h, it is a Å¿igne he knows not of his enemies. Secondly, By our pride. If a man

Thirdly, by our hard hearts. The heart of JoÅ¿iah melted when the Law Å¿hewed his errours: and the heart of Paul was wounded, and he died, when the Law came and made his errours live before him. Triplex circa praecordia ferrum. But we have armour of proof about our hearts. They do not melt, dye, nor are wounded with the Å¿ight of our errours: therefore we know them not.

UÅ¿e. 1 Therefore (I beÅ¿eech you) make good uÅ¿e of this point for information, humiliation, and exhortation. FirÅ¿t, let it teach us not to dream of a fulfilling of the Law in this life of our Å¿elves. If a man cannot know his errours, Å¿urely, he Å¿hall never finde his full obedience. What is

PapiÅ¿ts Å¿peak of a double fulfilling of the Law: the firÅ¿t is the travellers fulfilling it, 1 Viatorum. 2 ComprehenÅ¿orum. which is while men are militant in this life: this they Å¿ay, is, to love God above all, and our neighbours as our Å¿elves. The Å¿econd is the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors fulfilling of it, which is, when men are in Glory: this, they Å¿ay, is to love God with all our heart, minde, will, and Å¿trength. But indeed we have but one rule of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, which Å¿hould bee fulfilled with all our powers: and when God Å¿aith, Gal. 3. Inchoata
Imputatae
PerÅ¿onalis
Inchoate and begun, by equall, and Å¿incere obedience according to grace given. Imputed, by the Å¿atisfaction of our Å¿urety made ours: for the Law is then fulfilled when the breach of it is Å¿atisfied. And perÅ¿onall, and perfect, which Paul teacheth to be impoÅ¿sible becauÅ¿e of the fleÅ¿h. And, Rom 8.3. in truth, it muÅ¿t needs be Å¿o: for perÅ¿onall
fulfilling cannot Å¿tand with corruption in nature, and Å¿inne in life.
